III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that Youth A and Youth B have been engaging in
inappropriate and possible sexual relationship while at the facility.
They have written letters to each other describing the relationship
and these were recently found.
Investigation I spoke to Administrator on 9/17/24; no new information was
provided.
I left a voicemail for Complainant on 9/17/24. A return call was
not completed.
I spoke to DHHS Worker on 9/17/24. Allegations were discussed.
I contacted Foster Care Worker on 10/10/24. No new information
was provided.
Interviews were conducted on 9/20/24 at the facility.
Youth B reported he does not have a sexual relationship with
Youth A. Youth B reported he has hugged Youth A and has
touched her leg when he has talked to her. Youth B reported the
units do outside recreation together and they were able to be near
each other. Youth B reported they were able to sit together at the
picnic table and he touched her leg under the table once. Youth B
reported staff were present, they just didn’t see him do this. Youth
B reported he will verbally flirt with her, but they are not an “item.”
Youth B reported they both have written letters to each other.
Youth B reported they have passed the letters by giving them to
other individuals to hand to each other. Youth B reported males
and females are not separate in school, so he was able to pass
2

letters this way. They also used to have cafeteria meals together.
Youth B reported the cafeteria meals has been changed and now
meals are done by units; therefore, males and females are
separate. Youth B reported there was always a staff member in
addition to the teacher in the classroom. Youth B reported they
didn’t see them pass the notes. Youth B reported there were
always staff in the cafeteria as well. Youth B reported sometimes
he would drop letters on the ground if he knew Youth A was
behind him in class or in line and she would know to grab it. Youth
B reported when they AWOLed together, Youth A would grab his
groin area over his clothes, and he would grab her butt over her
clothes. Youth B reported they have kissed when they AWOLed
but did not engage in sexual intercourse. On 9/16/24, after their
AWOL, Supervisor 3 spoke to him about his decisions pertaining
to AWOL and questioning him concerning Youth A. After this
AWOL, staff in the unit made them keep their distance during
outside activities. Youth B reported no one knew they were
“talking” to each other.
Youth A reported her, and Youth B have never touched each
other. Youth A reported they AWOLed four days ago (9/16/24)
and during that AWOL there was no touching either. Youth A
reported she would give written letters by handing them to him.
Youth A reported staff were always present but didn’t see this
happen. Youth A reported she is 13 years of age and Youth B is
17 years of age and she does not want him to get into trouble, so
they never touched each other. Youth A would not discuss
anything further.
Supervisor 1 is the supervisor for Youth A’s unit. Supervisor 1
reported Youth A does attempt to gain attention from the male
youth in the building. Supervisor 1 reported she was unaware of
any involvement of Youth A and Youth B though. Supervisor 1
reported she thought Youth A was interested in a different male
peer and she was keeping an eye on this. Supervisor 1 reported
on 9/10/24, there was heightened supervision on Youth A. This
was due to Youth A showing an outward interest in male youth.
The interventions they put into place were to separate the units
during lunch time, separation from males in the school classroom,
and staff specifically monitoring Youth A in the Youth Council
Program. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A did not know staff were
supervising her, but the staff understood this to be their role.
Supervisor 1 reported Youth B had AWOLed with Youth A on
9/16/24 and then afterwards, they found the letters in a room
search. Supervisor 1 reported they never saw Youth A and Youth
B touching in any way.
3

Supervisor 2 is the supervisor for Youth B’s unit. Supervisor 2
reported Youth B is not involved in many issues. Youth B tends to
listen to instructions and is respectful to staff and peers.
Supervisor 2 reported they were not aware of any relationship until
after Youth A and Youth B AWOLed together on 9/16/24. After the
AWOL, they completed a room check for Youth A and Youth B
and found numerous letters under the dresser. Supervisor 2
reported no one had seen any touching or letter passing between
Youth A and Youth B.
Supervisor 3 is a facility supervisor. Supervisor 3 reported she
thought Youth A had a crush on Youth B, but that was it.
Supervisor 3 reported she has brought this up to Youth B as to
warn him to keep his distance from her, but never saw Youth B
interact with her in an inappropriate manner. Supervisor 3
reported they AWOLed recently and that is when they found out
there were letters written back and forth.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident Report dated 9/16/24. The incident report
documented an AWOL with Youth A and several other
peers. As they were AWOLing, “Youth B was very
inappropriate with touching, play fighting, holding hands,
and boundary lines.” The incident report noted they were
redirected many times but did not listen. They left the
grounds together hugging and in close proximity to one
another along with other peers. When they were AWOL
staff searched all the youth’s bedroom and found letters in
Youth A and Youth B’s bedrooms.
• I reviewed the letters between Youth A and Youth B. There
are no dates on the letters. Physical touch was mentioned
in the form of hugs and sitting next to each other. There
was not a specific reference to sexual activity that occurred,
only what Youth A wanted to happen sexually.
Analysis Based on all interviews, there is no evidence to suggest staff were
not present or not supervising youth.
• There is also no evidence to validate staff knew there was
a relationship and did not intervene to provide protection
and supervision.
• Staff are not accountable for youth’s behavior when they
are considered AWOL.
• Interventions were in place for Youth A, but not due to a
relationship with Youth B. Youth A has a tendency to
4

initiate relationships with the males in the building. Because
of this, the agency had already put interventions in place to
curb this behavior.
• Room checks were completed while youth were AWOL and
letters were discovered at that time.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
